pullRequest.body:
Contrary to what users would expect, this defines a global instance.

This linter would have caught #13144 and #13170.
[Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/ConcreteCategory.2EinstFunLike.20became.20a.20.20global.20instance)

Co-authored by: @adomani

---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I wrote a test yesterday (of course!), but forgot to commit it :facepalm: I've updated it to use your example instance now (and added you as an author of the tests), since this avoid mathlib imports.

I just tried the logic you proposed. It works, so I switched to it (and added you an an author).
I tweaked one test to consider nested syntax (which worked), so I guess `attribute`s are always the first syntax.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/6042e3db-2760-4fc6-a008-b7e413ca740f) for commit 627bf3ad22c5bc22738e391fcc2e8f85ff6dfc8d.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/e108ed5c-73c9-4e1b-a9c6-cd56000eb34d/to/6042e3db-2760-4fc6-a008-b7e413ca740f) against commit 49e1c29de1b78922c62e6e0cd04280bc742897f6.

Two minor requests, otherwise

bors d+

:v: grunweg can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks for the fast review.
bors r+

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9242495450/job/25425408870)
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9243678663/job/25428084098)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9243678663/job/25428084345)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9243678663/job/25428084676)
@grunweg Future idea for this linter: Catch #7678 as well.

I feel like I have had a bit of influence in this PR, so I am going to approve, but will not maintainer merge.

With respect to merging this linter into the "generic" one: I think that this can happen at a later stage, if/when the other PR is more ready.  At the moment, I still consider it experimental.

Thanks!

This looks good!

I do not know my way around `attribute` syntax, but is the alternative implementation below have some drawbacks?  It seems simpler to me.

Also, could you add a `#guard_msgs`ed test?

```lean
/-- Whether a syntax element is adding an `instance` attribute without a `local` modifier. -/
def is_attribute_instance_in : Syntax → Bool
  | `(command|attribute [instance] $_decl:ident in $_) => true
  | `(command|attribute [instance $_priority] $_decl:ident in $_) => true
  | _ => false

def attributeInstanceIn : Linter where run := withSetOptionIn fun stx => do
  unless getLinterAttributeInstanceIn (← getOptions) do
    return
  if (← MonadState.get).messages.hasErrors then
    return
  if is_attribute_instance_in stx then
    Linter.logLint linter.attributeInstanceIn stx[0] m!
      "careful: `attribute [instance] ... in` declarations are surprising: \
      they are **not** limited to the subsequent declaration, \
      but define global instances \
      please remove the `in` or make this a `local instance` instead"
```

I feel like I have had a bit of influence in this PR, so I am going to approve, but will not maintainer merge.

With respect to merging this linter into the "generic" one: I think that this can happen at a later stage, if/when the other PR is more ready.  At the moment, I still consider it experimental.

Thanks!

```suggestion
Despite the `in`, this makes `ConcreteCategory.instFunLike` a global instance.
```

```suggestion
      "careful: `attribute [instance] ... in` declarations are surprising: \
      they are **not** limited to the subsequent declaration, \
      but define global instances \
```
I wonder whether you actually wanted the indent or not.
I had not, and was puzzled about the indentation. Thanks, this solves it!

```suggestion
    if is_attribute_instance_in head then
```
I am not familiar with `findStack?`, but isn't this automatically true?  So, is this `if` necessary?
Oh, yes, this is also correct.
I do not have an opinion on this, but in `Mathlib` `m!` is never separated from its string.
The whole string is way too long for the line, but the `m!` must start on the same line as the `logLint` call... I've tried something in between now.

```suggestion
import Lean.Elab.Command
import Lean.Linter.Util
```
I do not know if you were tricked by `Shake`: this import is needed for `logLint`.
I was not tricked by shake - I removed this import manually and realised later that it wouldn't build...

```suggestion
```
Either remove careful, or change to some word already used to introduce linter explanations?

Fair point: this linter is not meant to be advisory, but a hard error - I have removed the "careful".
```suggestion
      "`attribute [instance] ... in` declarations are surprising:\n\
This should handle the case with multiple idents too
In fact, it should probably also accept a list of attributes that _contains_ `instance`

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: lint `attribute [instance] instName in`

nodes.body:
This looks good!

I do not know my way around `attribute` syntax, but is the alternative implementation below have some drawbacks?  It seems simpler to me.

Also, could you add a `#guard_msgs`ed test?

```lean
/-- Whether a syntax element is adding an `instance` attribute without a `local` modifier. -/
def is_attribute_instance_in : Syntax → Bool
  | `(command|attribute [instance] $_decl:ident in $_) => true
  | `(command|attribute [instance $_priority] $_decl:ident in $_) => true
  | _ => false

def attributeInstanceIn : Linter where run := withSetOptionIn fun stx => do
  unless getLinterAttributeInstanceIn (← getOptions) do
    return
  if (← MonadState.get).messages.hasErrors then
    return
  if is_attribute_instance_in stx then
    Linter.logLint linter.attributeInstanceIn stx[0] m!
      "careful: `attribute [instance] ... in` declarations are surprising: \
      they are **not** limited to the subsequent declaration, \
      but define global instances \
      please remove the `in` or make this a `local instance` instead"
```

source.title: feat: generic linter, absorbing `cdot` linter and `attribute [instance] in` linter
